StringWithMarkup.String: In a study in which 531 samples of grain and beans from the U.S., Japan, Australia, Korea, Canada and other countries were analyzed, the following food products detected piperonyl butoxide: 3 wheat from the U.S. (max concentraion 1.4 ppm); 1 barley from the U.S. (0.8 ppm); 2 barley from Australia (max concn 1.4 ppm); it was not detected (0.1 ppm detection limit) in hulled and unhulled rice, buck wheat, rye, oats, corn, milo, soy beans or red beans(1). Piperonyl butoxide was identified, not quantified (0.20 ppm limit of quantitation), in domestic and imported pears(2). Piperonyl butoxide was detected in 46 out of 769 domestic apples at a max concentration of 1.6 ppm and in 52 out of 1,062 imported apples at a maximum concentration of 0.47 ppm(3). The NY State Department of Agriculture detected piperonyl butoxide in three sweet potato samples at concentrations of 0.0003, 0.00017 and 0.007 ppm(4).

Section.Description: Other environmental concentrations reported for this chemical.

Reference: (1) McCauley LA et al; Environ Health Perspect 109: 533-8 (2001)
(2) Butte W, Heinzow B; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 175: 1-46 (2002)
(3) Rudel RA; J Air Waste Manage Assoc 51: 499-513 (2001)
(4) Stout DM et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 4294-300 (2009)

StringWithMarkup.String: Out of 73 farmworkers and growers in Washington and Hood River counties in Oregon, piperonyl butoxide was detected as residue in dust samples in one farmworker's home(1). Median concn and ranges of piperonyl butoxide detected in German house dust samples from vacuum cleaner bags (collected by the residents with commercial vacuums) were 0.11 and <0.1 to 270 mg/kg, respectively (2). Piperonyl butoxide was detected in 4 of 6 residential and office dust samples in Massachusetts at mean and range concns of 1.57 and 0.443-2.57 ug/g dust, respectively(3). Piperonyl butoxide was detected in 52% of 475 hard surface floor wipe samples from randomly selected nationally representative residential homes in the US from June 2005 to March 2006, at mean and max concns of 4.5 and 747 ng/sq cm, respectively(4).

Section.Description: Potential way(s) in which people may come into contact with a hazardous chemical.  Examples of common exposure routes are inhalation, ingestion, skin/eye contact.

Reference: (1) NIOSH; NOES. National Occupational Exposure Survey conducted from 1981-1983. Estimated numbers of employees potentially exposed to specific agents by 2-digit standard industrial classification (SIC). Available from, as of Sept 16, 2009: https://www.cdc.gov/noes/

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 89,064 workers (20,721 of these were female) were potentially exposed to piperonyl butoxide in the US(1). The NOES Survey does not include farm workers. Occupational exposure to piperonyl butoxide may occur through inhalation of dust and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where piperonyl butoxide is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to piperonyl butoxide via inhalation of dust, ingestion of food, and dermal contact with this compound or other insecticide products containing piperonyl butoxide(SRC).

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. These references have been ranked automatically by an algorithm which calculates the relevance for each substance in a Springer Nature document. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
